data.title: 51 Fun Things to do in Lucerne
data.meta_description: Discover fun things to do in Lucerne, Switzerland: visit the old town, enjoy a boat tour in Lake Lucern, check the views from Mount Pilatus, try the famous swiss chocolate and much more.
data.text:
When you’re walking through the enchanting streets of this lovely town, you’ll find yourself transported into a unique natural realm; and you’ll find it interspersed with plenty of creative and historical goodies, too!

While German is the main language spoken in Lucerne, it’s an undeniably Swiss town, from its mountaintops to its elegant buildings.

In fact, it’s the biggest city in Central Switzerland, hosting all sorts of different artistic and cultural outlets that really show off the region in all of its finery.

Of course, it’s a great portal to the past, from its traditional Old Town neighborhood to its gorgeous castles and bridges.

But the town also has its finger on the pulse of modern life, with an endless array of museums and culinary treats guaranteed to delight every palate.

Throw in some awesome art galleries, scenic hiking trails, and plenty of winter sports, and you have all the ingredients for an unbelievable vacation packed with great views and even greater adventures.

No matter the season, there are always amazing things to do in Lucerne – so let’s take a closer look!

1 – Wander around and discover the renowned structures of old town

Sure, the name probably gives you an idea of how long this area’s been around… but just wait until you start exploring!

This is no stuffy, archaic set of streets; around every corner, you’ll find gorgeous churches, quaint little buildings, and scenic bridges, all forming a nebulous architectural tapestry that reveals intriguing insights about the city itself.

As you admire the beauty of the structures and streets, you can also feel the weight of history in every cobblestone; this area has been an active part of community life since the medieval times, and some of those early landmarks are still around today!

One of the best ways to see the area is by embarking on a walking tour; follow your guide around the neighborhood as they regale you with its many stories and secrets – a truly unique experience!

walking tours in Lucerne

2 – Get in a mechanical state of mind at the Swiss Museum of Transport

Airplanes, cars, spaceships…. It’s like the toy chest of your childhood dreams!

And at the Swiss Museum of Transport, you’ll get to see some utterly awesome specimens up close!

Let your imagination and your sense of curiosity run wild as you wander past antique phones, scout out recreated railroad tunnels, or hop behind the controls of a flight simulator and get a taste of what it was like to pilot the real-life specimens all around you.

But believe it or not, there’s more here than just vehicles!

Stop by the Planetarium and experience the wonders of the cosmos, with a variety of thrilling, immersive shows that celebrate all of the wonders and complex mysteries of the universe. Take a seat and cast your eyes to the (virtual) stars – it’s a truly out-of-this-world experience!

Then enjoy a sweet treat with Swiss Chocolate Adventure, where you’ll wander around town trying all sorts of decadent desserts!

Swiss Museum of Transport tickets

3 – Lose yourself in the amazing shows of Filmtheatre at the Swiss Museum of Transport

But wait, there’s more!

This multifaceted museum is also home to the renowned Filmtheatre, where you can see the world in a spectacular, massive format.

As the biggest screen in Switzerland, it’s the perfect place to enjoy some phenomenal IMAX shows… especially if you’re a nature fan!

Trek along the slopes of Everest, come face to face with lions on the savannah, or dive deep into the colorful corals beneath the ocean waves – no scuba gear required!

There’s nothing quite like the thrill of seeing the world in this all-encompassing format… especially with the 3D option!

Filmtheatre at the Swiss Museum of Transport

4 – Ride the rails up Mount Pilatus

The clacking of the wheels, the giddy feeling of ascension, the stunning views that shift steadily as you climb – it’s a proper alpine adventure!

If you’re heading up Mount Pilatus, you can do so in style, aboard the planet’s steepest cogwheel railway!

This charming mode of transportation dates back to the 1800s, and is commonly used to carry guests up and down towering mountain slopes – the perfect option for a high-elevation place like Switzerland!

And just wait until you see what’s at the top!

Mount Pilatus itself is quite the sight to behold; its gorgeous scenery and jaw-dropping views make for an unforgettable day out – and best of all, it’s an easy day trip from the city!

Stroll around the summit and admire the craggy, elevated terrain that has made this mountain range so renowned around the world.

As you drink in the mythological tales of roving dragons and gaze out over the peaks and waterways below, you may be tempted never to come back down – but trust us, there’s lots more to see!

Mount Pilatus tours from Lucerne

5 – Admire the art on Chapel Bridge

As you stroll the streets of town, you may find yourself walking through a piece of history – or across it!

Believe it or not, this quaint, classically European bridge has been conveying citizens through town since the 1300s!

While the architecture of the bridge itself is utterly beautiful, it’s the inside that really makes it spectacular!

All along the interior of the rafters, you can see a dizzying array of portraits that depict stories from the town’s past, as well as the many saints that have been famed as protectors and symbols of the region.

It’s also a popular stop on various city tours in Lucerne, which will help you familiarize yourself with the ins and outs of this lovely town.

6 – See the beauty of Lake Lucerne up close by boat

Like the town it shares a name with, Lake Lucerne is breathtakingly beautiful, and filled with excitement.

While its distinctive shape is fascinating when viewed from up high, it’s an equally beautiful sight up close, with its sparkling blue waters and the unforgettable frame of the mountains.

And there’s no better way to appreciate it than with a boat tour!

Your sailing vessel will take you on an unforgettable journey through the water, learning all about the town and the adjacent natural wonders. From quaint little villages to postcard-perfect vistas, you’ll see the whole range of the region on these excursions – and the vehicles themselves are half the fun!

Choose between a cool, classy yacht, a lively catamaran, or even a stylish paddle steamer that dates all the way back to 1902!

And if you prefer your cruising to include a little more action, try out the excellent wakeboarding in Lucerne!

boat tours in Lucerne

7 – Take in the outdoor adventures and unique towns of the Interlaken region

Don’t worry, you’re not imagining things – Interlaken really is that beautiful!

Another unbelievably beautiful mountain town, this little hamlet has a decidedly peaceful air… but it’s also an adrenaline-riddled outdoor destination!

Whether you’re navigating a raft down some thrilling rapids or leaping into the void -safely attached to a bungee cord, of course – you’ll have an infinite array of action opportunities before you!

And if you’d prefer a more sedate excursion, you can browse through the various shops, or just take some time to amble along the quiet streets and enjoy the classic architecture.

And in the midst of your tour, you may catch sight of a particularly thrilling attraction, courtesy of the Grindelwald tours from Lucerne. With a nickname like “Glacier Village,” you know that the place will be stunning; and this little town’s gorgeous backdrop of mountainous ice formations make it a must-see.

Then keep the adventure going with a trip to the Bernese Oberlands, home to some of the area’s prettiest mountains and quaintest little villages.

Enjoy the fresh air and unparalleled, iconally Swiss views!

Interlaken tours from Lucerne

8 – Enjoy a refreshing hike on Mount Titlis

If you’re in more of a wintry frame of mind, you’re in luck; Mount Titlis is famed for its consistent dusting of snow!

Set out in an aerial tram and immerse yourself in this powdery paradise, where inner tubing, ice cave exploration, and strolls along the continent’s highest suspension bridge are all available to try out.

And if the weather’s warmer, it’s also a perfect place to do some hiking!

With a wide variety of trails for every interest level, you’ll have endless opportunities to enjoy the wonders of the mountain at your own pace.

That being said, there are also a lot of great guided options if you want to learn more about the landscape – plus, they’re a wonderful way to make some friends!

Mount Titlis tours from Lucerne

9 – Check out the instruments at the Church of St. Leodegar

Known for its soaring twin spires, this magnificent church is older than the country itself!

The spiritual roots of the site date all the way back to the 700s, when a monastery was built there; the first version of the church burned down in the 1600s, and after being rebuilt, it turned into a community hub.

While the building is impressive, and its musical offerings are especially spectacular!

Listen to the billowing sounds of the massive pipe organ, or the unique rhythms of the rain machine, a slowly spinning drum with metal balls inside that uncannily mimics the sound of a gentle storm.

This irresistible combination of history and art will leave you enthralled!

10 – Pay your respects at the Lion Monument

In 1792, nearly 1,000 valiant Swiss soldiers lost their lives defending King Louis XVI of France during the French Revolution.

And while that part of the narrative does not always make it into the history books, the people of Switzerland have not forgotten.

A visit to the Lion Monument is one of the most powerful and emotionally moving things to do in Lucerne, and a fitting testament to that tragic day.

Originally built by a guardsman who was not present at the conflict, the massive sculpture is carved directly into a massive rock, surrounded by a tranquil pond.

With its intricate designs and melancholy air, the stonework has drawn visitors from all over the globe, and is widely considered to be a pinnacle of the form.

While this piece has a somber backstory, it’s also a place of beauty and contemplation, and well worth stopping by.

11 – Try a bit of everything at Glacier Garden

You may not think of rocks and ice as particularly exciting, but once you see the spectacular Swiss landscape, you’ll change your mind!

And you’ll feel particularly enlightened after a trip to Glacier Garden, one of the city’s greatest natural treasures.

Some of the most interesting specimens catch the eye right away: a series of gaping glacial pots!

These cavernous holes of eroded stone are covered in brilliant patterns shaped over millions of years, with traces of Ice Age plants and animals still imprinted in their ridges.

You can also stop by the museum to learn more about the local natural history, and explore the eccentric collections of the Amrein family, who first developed this area into a tourist attraction.

Throw in a mirror maze, art installations, and a marvelous scenic trail, and you have a glorious treat for geology fans and generally curious types alike!

12 – Savor the unique atmosphere of Candlelight concerts

There’s nothing like a bit of music to make an evening memorable… especially an epic concert by candlelight!

Taking the classic evening entertainment to the next level, and enjoy stunning renditions of iconic symphony pieces, pop hits, and everything in between.

There’s also a sense of novelty to each performance, because they’re held in different venues around town, offering the chance to see all of these spots in a new and exciting light.

Sit back, relax, and enjoy the melding of sight and sound!

See price & reviews

13 – Get above it all (literally) at Jungfraujoch

As another one of the region’s splendid mountainous peaks, Jungfraujoch is one of the loveliest parts of the alpine range – which is really saying something!

Take advantage of a guided tour to reach these peaks in comfort and style, and spend more time exploring the trails and gorgeous views.

Often dubbed “The Top of Europe,” this magnificent mountainous region is also home to the highest railway station on the continent, as well as an entire palace made of ice!

Soaring 11,333 feet (3,454 meters) above sea level, it offers some unbelievable scenery, and you’ll never forget your dizzying, exhilarating day at one of the continent’s high points!

Jungfraujoch tours from Lucerne

14 – Use paragliding to get some new views

If all of these mountainous adventures still aren’t giving you the vantage point you hoped for, what about actually taking to the sky?

There’s nothing quite like paragliding over the mountains and valleys of central Switzerland, with small villages perfectly blending into the rolling meadows and around the lakes.

No prior experience is necessary for this adventure; you’ll fly in the company of an experienced guide, who will focus on the technical aspects and point out some of the amazing views before you.

But even if you’ve done this a million times before, it will be a flight to remember!

paragliding in Lucerne

15 – Take a side trip into religious history at the Jesuit Church

Among the many religious orders that have played a role in the city’s history, the Jesuits were among the most prominent – and they left a memorable souvenir that continues to add to the skyline!

The Jesuit Church opened in 1677, and served as a spiritual home for local Catholic worshippers.

As the first Baroque-style religious building in the country, its elegant decor and eye-catching onion dome steeples make for a truly breathtaking tribute to construction methods of the era.

While the building no longer holds regular services, it does feature plenty of musical performances (the organ is particularly popular here), and you can still tour the building for a glimpse into this unique religious society.

16 – Zoom upwards on the Hammetschwand Elevator

Believe it or not, Lucerne is home to yet another awesome alpine milestone!

The Hammetschwand Elevator is not only the continent’s tallest outdoor lift, but it has an amazing destination at the end of the ride: Bürgenstock Mountain!

While you can still enjoy the same benefits as other mountains in the area – including great views and excellent trekking trails -, it also has the added bonus of luxury accommodations, courtesy of the Burgenstock Resort.

For almost 150 years, this spectacular hotel has offered great sights and plenty of fresh air, as well as a wonderfully secluded experience – nothing like being on top of a mountain to get away from it all!

But of course, the elevator itself is half the fun!

Climb aboard and rise slowly up the side of the mountain, watching the valley and Lake Lucerne shrink, and the peak of the mountain get closer.

It’s so much more than your average lift ride!

17 – Hit the slopes at some of the best nearby ski resorts

When the winter rolls around and the snow starts falling, there’s another thing to do in town: skiing, and lots of it!

Some of the country’s best resorts are just a short distance from town, offering slopes that have drawn the eye of powderhounds the world over.

Check out the lakeside splendor of Klewenalp, which also includes the longest toboggan run in the region.

Or head out to the charming village of Engelberg, known for its quaint surroundings and massive variety of runs, which also include sledding and snowboarding areas.

You can even book lessons with a private instructor to work on your technique – a worthy investment if you want to maximize your time on these world-famous trails!

skiing near Lucerne

18 – Engage in the humanities at the Lucerne Culture and Congress Centre

Sure, the outdoorsy endeavors are top-notch here; but it’s well worth checking out some of the humanities-focused options in town.

The Lucerne Culture and Congress Centre is one of the best places to catch a show or presentation, especially if you’re a fan of live music!

The building’s concert hall is a top-notch venue, with renowned acoustics and an eclectic assortment of performers that make each visit a unique treat.

Its convention center also hosts a wide array of events throughout the year, plus a great art gallery that provides a steady stream of beautiful works to admire.

You never know quite what you’ll find here, but it’s guaranteed to be amazing!

19 – Enjoy the unforgettable sensation of freefall while skydiving over Lake Lucerne

The wind whips past your face as you plunge past the clouds, the seemingly endless expanse of Lake Lucerne spread out below you.

No, it’s not a dream; you’re skydiving over one of the most beautiful spots in Europe!

Much like paragliding, this thrilling sport combines the feeling of flight with the incredible views of the surrounding area, but it takes things to the next level… literally!

From a lofty vantage point of 13,000 feet, you’ll pair up with your instructor and leap into the atmosphere, soaring towards the Earth in a thrilling fashion.

It’s the closest you can come to being a bird!

skydiving in Lucerne

20 – Browse through the masterpieces of the Kunstmuseum Luzern

Innovative, engaging, and eclectic, this marvelous art museum is packed with creativity!

The primary focus is on Swiss pieces from the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries, including works by such masters as Ferdinand Hodler, Felix Maria Diogg, and Kaspar Meglinger.

The Kunstmuseum Luzern is also renowned for its annual themed exhibitions, displaying samples from its remarkable collection that are all linked by an overarching concept.

Sometimes, they focus on specific mediums, such as paintings; other times, it’s the subjects of the art themselves that are the unifying focus, such as various types of animals.

Stroll amongst the works, and get an eyeful of beauty, all arranged in an innovative style that will help you put these movements into better perspective.

21 – Take in the full scope of the past at the Bourbaki Panorama

It’s often said that museums help make history come alive, and the Bourbaki Panorama does so in a practically cinematic fashion!

The artform, which consists of a massive circular painting that fills up an entire room, was once one of the most popular and revered in the museum world, and the versions that still exist today are all considered impressive relics.

This particular display showcases a fascinating historical incident: in 1871, 87,000 French soldiers crossed the border to Switzerland to avoid ongoing war, and were granted sanctuary – a move that has been said to have kickstarter the country’s tradition of global neutrality.

Take your time walking around the room and absorb every detail of the massive portrait; each brushstroke tells a story about this pivotal moment in time, with all the color and texture that a good painting can provide.

22 – Stretch your legs with the many excellent hiking trails around Mount Rigi

At a magisterial 5,899 feet above sea level, Mount Rigi is the perfect family-friendly excursion!

Like so many of its beautiful contemporaries, it has a system of trains running up, down, and around the topography, offering plenty of spectacular opportunities to enjoy the scenery.

It’s also well worth getting out to hike around and see the beauty up close, courtesy of the hiking trails that run all along the ridges.

From mellow trails suitable for all ages to invigorating jaunts between points of the peak, each route offers a chance to lose yourself in the vibrant beauty of the area, with forest and meadows embracing you as you gaze out at the land beyond.

You’ll soon see why this spectacular ridge has been dubbed “The Queen of The Mountains”!

Mount Rigi tours from Lucerne

23 – Wander the wilderness of the Entlebuch Biosphere

How often do you get to walk around in a forest that’s protected by UNESCO?

The Entlebuch Biosphere is a truly idyllic place, and it has the added bonus of serving as a conservation site for some of the country’s most beautiful ecosystems.

Stroll through comforting forests of pine trees, and enjoy the sunshine on your face as you stand in lush open fields.

This spacious landscape is a perfect showcase of the pre-Alpine moorland ecosystem, so when you walk around here, you’re not just enjoying a peaceful hike; you’re also going back in time, to a world of nature at its finest and most primal.

As you pass by the silhouette of Schrattenfluh Mountain, you’ll feel more connected than ever to the wild, wonderful world!

24 – Take a scenic stroll along the centuries-old Spreuer Bridge

This pretty path has a somewhat unromantic backstory: when it was first built in the 1400s, the local mills used to swing by and dump their leftover rubbish into the river.

But it’s certainly had a glow-up since then!

The simple wooden bridge remains largely similar to how it was 600 years ago, but like the neighboring Chapel Bridge, it features an elaborate series of pictures inside, many of which date back to the Middle Ages.

There’s also a small chapel built into the structure, so you can get a somewhat more tranquil experience in between all of the beautifully eerie, death-focused portraits that dominate the space.

Snag an audio tour from the Historical Museum of Lucerne if you want to learn even more about this magnificent creation!

25 – See the man behind the music at the Richard Wagner Museum

Classical music fans, rejoice; one of opera’s greatest talents once called this town home, and you can visit a wonderful museum built in his honor!

Renowned composer Richard Wagner lived and worked all over Europe, but the six years that he spent in Lucerne were hugely influential on both a personal and professional level.

In addition to creating some of his most beloved works, the beautiful country home served as a welcoming, lively residence for the artist and his family.

As you explore this gorgeous residence, you can enjoy an impressive collection of artifacts, from historical paintings and furniture to original manuscripts of the musical scores crafted by the master himself.

26 – Sleep in a Castle

Looking for some particularly fancy things to do in Lucerne?

How about bedding down for the night in an actual castle?

Château Gütsch dates back to the 1800s, and its luxurious trappings make for an ideal getaway right in the heart of town – one that, as an added bonus, is filled with history!

The magnificent building has a great vantage point above town, perfectly perched on a hill that was once used to scout for invaders.

Inside, you’ll be able to enjoy world-class decor, a fantastic restaurant, and a spacious terrace perfect for enjoying the views.

And when you’re ready for a bit of adventure, the Lion Monument, the Chapel Bridge, and the city’s other great attractions are just a short walk away.

When you stay here, you’ll really feel like royalty!

Château Gütsch Hotel

27 – Soar over some amazing sights on a helicopter flight

Have you ever wanted to hover around the mountains?

How about doing so with a running commentary on all of the cool sights below you?

Then book a helicopter flight and prepare to be amazed!

These choppers are perfect for exploring the varied terrain from a whole new vantage point, dipping and gliding over Lake Lucerne and the curves of the mountains.

And if you want to take things to the next level, you can actually fly the craft yourself!

Hop in the co-pilot seat and learn the controls, then enjoy the unique thrill of piloting over the scenery – you’ll feel like a real action star!

helicopter tours in Lucerne

28 – Step into the past – or spend the night there! – at Heidegg Castle

Believe it or not, there’s more than one regal residence where you can spend an evening!

Heidegg Castle is a little bit older – it first got mentioned in the late 1100s! -, and it has seen the city through many ups and downs, from shifting political regimes to invading armies.

Nowadays, it serves as a combination of historic site, luxury stay, and cultural space, inviting visitors to explore the past while enjoying all of the amenities of the present.

Don’t miss the living history museum, which captures the furniture and interior design choices of several centuries’ worth of residents.

And yes, you can even book a room there- talk about a stay with a story!

29 – Try famous swiss chocolate

When you think of Switzerland, your mouth may start to water at the thought of cheese and chocolate.

And you can certainly delve into the sweet side of things in Lucerne!

Get straight to the fun with some chocolate tastings, where you can explore various shops and factories to sample the wares (you’ll want to try as many as possible to be thorough in your research, of course!).

And don’t miss Aeschbach Chocolatier, an extravagant space filled with free samples, interactive exhibits, and even a gallery full of works made from, you guessed it, chocolate!

As the home of the world-famous chocolate coin, this factory has an unbeatable pedigree, and it’s well worth stopping by to sample it!

chocolate tastings in Lucerne

30 – Enjoy the community vibes of Inseli Park

If you want to get a feel for day-to-day life in town, head over to this lovely public space for a relaxing afternoon.

Perfectly situated along the lake, the park has something for everyone, from its lively playground to the many nearby cafes perfect for a bit of unwinding.

There are also plenty of scenic paths if you want to squeeze in a quick run or a picturesque stroll.

And of course, the views are phenomenal; if you want some to really linger on the scenery, this is the place to do it! Take some time to enjoy the atmosphere right alongside the locals!

31 – Soak up the legacies of the Franciscan church

From its Gothic designs to its beautiful grounds, this stunning church hearkens back to the 1200s, when the local Franciscan order first established themselves.

Over the years, it has served as a place of refuge for community members in need, as well as wandering pilgrims.

Along with its welcoming reputation, the church was known for its wonderfully detailed artwork, much of which can still be seen today.

Its design is also an amazing collection of styles, the result of continual rebuilding efforts; it’s like a crash course in architecture over several hundred years, all in one building!

Keep an eye out for the flags atop the higher walls, which mark the victorious battles of various Swiss soldiers in the 1600s.

The building also happens to be located on Franziskanerplatz, one of the liveliest streets in town; if you’re visiting during the holidays, be sure to stop by the fabulous Christmas market!

32 – Enjoy unforgettable views at Stanserhorn

From the minute you step aboard the Cabrio cable car and start gliding upwards, you’ll fall in love with Stanserhorn!

Once you’ve reached the top, you can join up with a ranger and explore the area, admiring the gorgeous wildflowers and keeping an eye out for eagles gliding overhead.

Take some time to enjoy a meal at the restaurant on the peak, then head back down on the same lovely tram, which is the only one in the world to offer an open upper deck.

If you feel daring enough to head up top and take a look around, you’ll be rewarded with an unbelievable panoramic view, the wind in your face, and the sense that you are truly on top of the world – if only for a moment!

33 – Treat the kids to an adventure at Meggenhorn Castle

If you’re looking for a palatial space with a more family-friendly feel, Meggenhorn Castle has got you covered!

This splendid building is equally famed for the gardens that surround it; along with great views of both the castle above and the lake below, the grounds themselves are the picture of aesthetic beauty.

You can also enjoy great views of the vineyards below, then take the youngsters over to the playground to meet some friendly farm animals.

And if you happen to be visiting on a Sunday between April and October, you can even tour some of the rooms inside the castle – a great opportunity to see how the other half once lived!

34 – Utilize some pedaling power with various bike tours

While this city has great walkability value, it’s also fun to see on two wheels!

Bike tours are eco-friendly, efficient, and tons of fun, and the perfect option if you want to explore some of the natural wonders around town.

Whether you’re pedaling through the scenic Knife Valley – rumored to have been the home of the legendary William Tell – or following the curve of Lake Lucerne’s mighty shoreline, you’ll get a new perspective on the terrain, and learn lots of cool facts along the way.

Some tours can even be combined with a boat cruise, so you can see even more!

bike tours in Lucerne

35 – Put an innovative spin on your sightseeing with foxtrail

It’s not every day that you get to mix an old elite tradition with a new technological adventure, but in Lucerne, anything is possible!

From the minute you set out on a foxtrail, you’ll be immersed in exciting puzzles and fun riddles, as you chase a virtual fox through the city from one point to the next.

Enjoy an immersive, inventive trip through the streets of town, with your wily prey inadvertently guiding you through history and culture at a quick pace.

And don’t worry, you won’t be doing this alone; half the fun lies in the collaboration with your teammates, as you work together to reach the end of your epic quest!

36 – Enjoy an idyllic lake day at Rotsee Badi

When the sun comes out and the air warms up, it’s time to head to the local swimming hole… and what a marvelous spot it is!

Framed by a pastoral ring of hills and trees, Rotsee Badi is the perfect place to go for a dip, with fresh, clear lake water that practically begs to be cannonballed into!

It also offers a refreshing amount of variety, with kiddie pools and soaking spots for non-swimmers in addition to the open water.

And if you’re more of a wild type, give the slide and the diving boards a whirl!

The whole area has a comfortably social atmosphere, often hosting concerts, yoga sessions, and more; but it’s also easy to just laze away a whole day sunbathing on the shore!

37 – Lace up your boots and do some serious hiking

The mountains here are truly dizzying to behold… and even more exhilarating to conquer!

There’s some truly incredible hiking to be had here, so lace up your boots and make your way across some wonderful cross-sections of the Alps!

Visit iconic spots like Mount Pilatus and Mount Rigi, where you can happily spend an entire day roaming the grassy slopes and enjoying beautiful views at every turn.

Or take some more focused routes, like the one that revisits the old haunts of the legendary William Tell.

Push your physical limits, then reward yourself with an unfettered dose of nature!

hiking near Lucerne

38 – Explore some iconic art movements at Museum Sammlung Rosengart

From Picasso to Renoir, you’re always in good company at the Rosengart!

With a focus on Classic Modernism and Impressionism, this space is a little smaller and more concentrated than its contemporaries; but this certainly doesn’t mean that it’s lacking in representation of talent!

Take a guided tour to put the works in greater context, or spend some time lingering in each of the galleries, admiring these pieces individually and in relation to each other.

Don’t miss the massive gallery showcasing the creations of Paul Klee, famed for his vividly colored, pattern-filled oil paintings and watercolors.

39 – Get a good dose of dairy with some cheese tastings

There are a few tastes that automatically get associated with Switzerland, and you can feast your way through some of the most popular ones with the savory, succulent cheese tastings in Lucerne!

Explore the delightful world of dairy at various spots around town, nibbling on all sorts of vividly flavored styles crafted through centuries of tradition.

And of course, nothing goes better with these savory goods than a little something sweet, which is why the excursions usually throw in a chocolate tasting as well.

Spend the day nibbling your way through the country’s classic exports!

40 – Enjoy the blend of art and nature at Dreilinden Park

As you amble between gorgeous groves of trees, you’ll periodically come across a stunning view of the Alps, standing out tall and proud against the skyline

And along the way, you may just hear the faint, beautiful sounds of musicians at work, adding a beautiful soundtrack to the scene.

It’s no wonder that a visit to Dreilinden Park is considered one of the best things to do in Lucerne!

As the biggest public park in town, it provides not only a tranquil getaway, but also some wonderful social amenities, including sculptures, historic buildings, and the Lucerne School of Music, where so many great talents have been nurtured.

It’s a spectacular space, whether you’re there for one hour or several!

41 – Take a walk on the wild side at Toni’s Zoo

Time to meet some new friends of the feathered and furry variety! There are over 400 critters living here, from penguins and monkeys to macaws, iguanas, and cheetahs.

And while just looking at the many different animals from around the world is cool enough, there are also tons of excellent tours that let you peek behind the scenes and learn more about these lovely creatures and their unique traits.

It’s a great way for kids to learn more about nature in all of its amazing forms… and grown-up chaperones and nature fans will have a great time too!

42 – Put your sleuth skills to the test with some scavenger games

If you like learning in unorthodox ways and at your own pace, you’ll love the local scavenger games! Download the app and embark on an exciting adventure, combining walking tours, audio tours, and puzzle-solving.

This interactive format takes you behind the scenes of some of the most famous attractions, while also highlighting hidden stories. As you bounce from one spot to the next, you’ll also get the thrill of unlocking each new clue or location like a modern-day spy.

And best of all, it’s entirely self-guided, so you can stop and start whenever you want.

It’s the perfect way to ignite your curiosity and sense of fun, while learning tons along the way!

scavenger games in Lucerne

43 – Enjoy the rich history of Musegg Wall and its nine towers

With its eye-catching structures and elegant roofs, Musegg Wall is hard to miss – and it’s been a part of the landscape for centuries!

Built as a fortifying structure for the city in the 1200s, the mighty wall added more and more towers over the years, each with its own distinct style and function.

From the observation post of the Luegisland Tower to the massive clock adorning the Zyt Tower, these structures have become so much more than mere watchposts.
